questions.text: Which of the following drugs has dual activity against both hepatitis B as well as HIV? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tenofovir


Tenofovir is an antiretroviral medication that has been shown to have dual activity against both HIV and hepatitis B virus (HBV). It is commonly used in the treatment of both infections. Tenofovir works by inhibiting the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is essential for the replication of both viruses, thereby reducing viral load in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abacavir: Abacavir is an antiretroviral drug used primarily for HIV treatment but does not have significant activity against hepatitis B.

 

Option C. Ritonavir: Ritonavir is used to boost the effects of other HIV medications but does not have activity against hepatitis B.

 

Option D. Dolutegravir: Dolutegravir is another antiretroviral used for HIV but lacks significant efficacy against hepatitis B.

 

Educational Objective:


Drug with dual activity against both HIV and hepatitis B: (Mnemonic: LET)

  • Lamivudine
  • Emtricitabine
  • Tenofovir

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pre-gestational diabetes

 

Explanation

 

The image shows a condition known as mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia, which is a rare congenital deformity characterized by the fusion of the lower limbs. This condition is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) diabetes mellitus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sirenomelia (mermaid syndrome) is strongly linked to maternal pre-gestational diabetes.
  • Overt diabetes mellitus during pregnancy is known to cause various congenital anomalies, with cardiac anomalies being the most common, specifically ventricular septal defects (VSD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes typically occurs later in pregnancy and does not usually cause congenital anomalies, as organogenesis is largely complete by the time gestational diabetes is diagnosed.

 

Option C. Effect of valproate: Valproate exposure during pregnancy is associated with neural tube defects, facial anomalies (such as cleft lip and palate), and cardiac anomalies, but not sirenomelia.

 

Option D. Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers reduce fetal renal perfusion, leading to conditions such as oligohydramnios and subsequent pulmonary hypoplasia, but they do not cause sirenomelia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pre-gestational diabetes is associated with an increased risk of congenital anomalies, including mermaid syndrome (sirenomelia), characterized by the fusion of lower limbs.

 

Ref: Page 384, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: In the mid-axillary line, the right costo-phrenic recess extends up to the level of which rib? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. 10th

 

The pleura (parietal pleura) extends beyond the lung, forming recesses that allow for lung expansion during respiration. At the mid-axillary line, the pleura extends down to the 10th rib, while the lung itself ends at the 8th rib in this line. This creates the costodiaphragmatic recess, which is an important potential space for pleural fluid collection. This anatomical relationship is clinically significant because it makes the area between the 8th and 10th ribs in the mid-axillary line an ideal location for thoracentesis (pleural tapping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6th - This is incorrect as the pleura extends much lower than the 6th rib in the mid-axillary line. The 6th rib marks approximately where the pleura crosses in the mid-clavicular line, not the mid-axillary line.

 

Option C. 8th - The 8th rib in the mid-axillary line marks the lower border of the lung, not the pleura. The pleural reflection extends further down to create the costodiaphragmatic recess.

 

Option D. 12th - The pleura does not extend as far down as the 12th rib in the mid-axillary line. The pleura reaches the 12th rib posteriorly near the vertebral column, not in the mid-axillary line.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The pleura extends to the 10th rib in the mid-axillary line while the lung ends at the 8th rib, creating a costodiaphragmatic recess between the 8th-10th ribs that is clinically important for thoracentesis procedures.

questions.text: As per United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, Targets for MMR and U5MR to be achieved by 2030 are: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 70 MMR, 25 U5MR

 

The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) were established in 2016 as a global agenda to be achieved by 2030. Among the 17 goals outlined, Goal 3 is specifically focused on health and well-being.

 

Under this goal:

 

  • Target 3.1 aims to reduce the global maternal mortality ratio (MMR) to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
  • Target 3.2 focuses on reducing the under-5 mortality rate (U5MR) to 25 per 1,000 live births and neonatal mortality to 12 per 1,000 live births.

 

These targets are part of a broader effort to improve health outcomes and ensure universal health coverage by 2030.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The United Nations Sustainable Development Goals aim to reduce the maternal mortality ratio to below 70 per 100,000 live births and the under-5 mortality rate to 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030.

questions.text: In a standard normal distribution, what percentage of data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 68%

 

In a standard normal distribution, the data is symmetrically distributed around the mean, forming a bell-shaped curve known as the Gaussian distribution. This distribution is characterized by the following properties:

 

  • The mean, median, and mode of the distribution are equal and located at the center of the curve.
  • The curve is bilaterally symmetrical, meaning if a perpendicular line is drawn from the top of the curve, it divides the graph into two equal halves.

 

One of the key features of a standard normal distribution is that it follows the empirical rule, which states:

 

 

Therefore, the percentage of data values that fall within one standard deviation of the mean in a standard normal distribution is approximately 68%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a standard normal distribution, 68% of the data values fall within one standard deviation of the mean.

questions.text: A male present with grouped painful vesicular lesions in the genital area. History of multiple sexual partners present. Irregular use of condoms history present. Smear showed MNGCs. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes genitalis

 

Herpes genitalis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). The presentation of grouped painful vesicular lesions on an erythematous base in the genital area, especially in a patient with a history of multiple sexual partners and irregular condom use, is highly suggestive of herpes genitalis. The presence of multinucleated giant cells (MNGCs) on a smear is a key diagnostic feature of HSV infection. This is because HSV causes the fusion of infected cells, leading to the formation of these giant cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes zoster: Herpes zoster (shingles) typically presents as painful vesicular lesions following a dermatomal distribution, usually on one side of the body. The lesions do not cluster in the genital area unless the sacral nerve is involved, which is uncommon. Also, the absence of a dermatomal pattern makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Warts: Genital warts, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), present as painless, cauliflower-like growths rather than painful vesicular lesions. The description of painful lesions and the presence of MNGCs on the smear make this option unlikely.

 

Option D. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents as a painful genital ulcer with ragged edges and undermined borders. It does not present with vesicular lesions or MNGCs on a smear, making this diagnosis incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes genitalis should be considered when a patient presents with grouped painful vesicular lesions in the genital area, especially when there is a history of risky sexual behavior and multinucleated giant cells are observed on a smear.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely disease looking at the pattern of inheritance as provided in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

The pedigree in the image shows an inheritance pattern typical of X-linked recessive conditions. In this pattern, affected males inherit the disease from carrier mothers, while females are usually carriers and do not show the disease. All affected individuals are male, and carrier females are represented by circles with a dot. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome follows an X-linked recessive inheritance, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wilson’s disease: This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning both males and females are equally affected, and carriers are not seen in the pattern observed here.

 

Option C. Achondroplasia: This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. It would appear in every generation and affect both males and females equally, which is not the case in the presented pedigree.

 

Option D. Leber disease: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is inherited through maternal (mitochondrial) inheritance. It does not follow an X-linked recessive pattern and affects both sexes through maternal transmission only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked recessive conditions are characterized by affected males and carrier females, as males have only one X chromosome, making them susceptible if the gene is defective.

 

Major X-linked Recessive Disorders (Mnemonic: "OBLIGATE")

 

 

Other X-linked Recessive Diseases:

choices.text: Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center
Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother on how to feed

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy is found to weigh 8kg. A WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) is provided below. Plot the growth chart for this child. What is the most appropriate advice based on the plotted graph? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother on how to feed

 

The WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) shows that the weight of 8 kg for a 16-month-old boy falls between -2 standard deviations (SD) and -3 SD, indicating moderate malnutrition. This suggests that the child is not receiving adequate nutrition and is at risk for growth and developmental delays.

 

In such cases, it is important to educate the mother on proper feeding practices to ensure the child receives a balanced diet with adequate nutrients. This can involve guidance on meal frequency, food variety, and portion sizes to improve the child's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No malnutrition - Assure the mother: This option is incorrect because the child’s weight for height falls between -2SD and -3SD on the growth chart, indicating moderate malnutrition rather than no malnutrition.

 

Option B. Mild malnutrition - home treatment: This option is incorrect as mild malnutrition is indicated when the weight-for-height is between -1SD and -2SD. The child’s weight falls between -2SD and -3SD, indicating moderate malnutrition.

 

Option C. Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center: This option is incorrect because severe malnutrition is diagnosed when the weight-for-height is less than -3SD. The child’s weight does not fall into this category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Moderate malnutrition in children is indicated by a weight-for-height between -2SD and -3SD on the WHO growth chart, necessitating education on proper feeding practices.

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs is preferred in a patient with heart and kidney disease? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SGLT-2 inhibitors

 

Explanation: 

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors (drugs ending in -gliflozin like canagliflozin, empagliflozin, dapagliflozin) are the preferred choice because:

 

  • They work by inhibiting SGLT-2 in proximal tubules, preventing reabsorption of both glucose and sodium
  • They reduce mortality in patients with congestive heart failure
  • They slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease
  • Their mechanism of promoting glucose and sodium excretion provides cardiovascular and renal benefits beyond glycemic control

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biguanides (Incorrect)

 

  • While effective for diabetes, metformin (Biguanides) has limitations in patients with significant kidney disease
  • Must be used cautiously or avoided in patients with renal impairment due to risk of lactic acidosis
  • Does not provide direct cardiovascular benefits like SGLT-2 inhibitors

 

Option B. GLP-1 analogs (Incorrect)

 

  • While they have some cardiovascular benefits, they don't have the same level of evidence for combined cardiac and renal protection as SGLT-2 inhibitors

 

Option D. Sulfonylureas (Incorrect)

 

  • Associated with risk of hypoglycemia
  • No proven cardiovascular benefits
  • May need dose adjustment in kidney disease
  • Can cause fluid retention which may worsen heart failure

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors are the preferred antidiabetic agents in patients with coexisting heart and kidney disease due to their proven benefits in reducing cardiovascular mortality and slowing the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

choices.text: Telomere stability is associated with aging
Abnormal telomerase activation is associated with aging
Decreased telomere length is associated with aging
Increased telomere length is associated with aging

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the telomerase theory of aging? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased telomere length is associated with aging.

 

  • Telomeres are short, TG-rich repeated DNA sequences found at the ends of linear eukaryotic chromosomes. Telomeres do not contain any protein coding sequences. They are necessary for the complete replication of chromosome ends as well as the protection of the ends from fusion and degradation.
  • Telomeres at the ends of chromosomes are normally shortened with each cell division. Cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis may result if telomeres are shortened beyond a certain point. This is referred to as replicative senescence.
  • Telomerase is an enzyme that prevents telomeres from shortening. It is a specialized RNA-protein complex that adds nucleotides to the ends of chromosomes by using its own RNA as a template.
  • This enzyme is found in germ cells but not in most somatic cells. As a result, the majority of somatic cells age, their telomeres shorten, and they exit the cell cycle, rendering them unable to generate new cells to replace damaged cells.
  • In somatic cells, abnormal telomerase reactivation causes senescence and apoptosis. It allows the cells to divide more than usual.
  • Telomerase is usually reactivated in stem cells and cancer cells, and telomere length is stabilized, allowing the cells to proliferate indefinitely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased telomere length is associated with aging. Telomeres shorten with each cell division, leading to cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis when they become critically short, contributing to the aging process. Telomerase helps prevent this shortening but is typically inactive in most somatic cells, leading to aging and limited cell division capability.

choices.text: MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother
MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctor’s opinion only

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to your hospital emergency with pregnancy 22 weeks, which was a result of rape. Correct statement regarding Medical Termination of Pregnancy is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act of India, MTP is permitted up to 24 weeks of pregnancy. For gestation periods from 0 to 20 weeks, it is considered low risk and only one doctor’s opinion is required.

 

However, for gestation periods from 20 to 24 weeks, it is categorized as high risk, and the approval of two doctors is required. This high-risk category includes specific situations such as rape, incest, disability, and when the woman is a minor. Since the woman in the question is 22 weeks pregnant due to rape, MTP is permissible under these regulations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP can be done routinely after 24 weeks POG: This is incorrect because MTP after 24 weeks is not routinely allowed. It requires a medical board's approval and is only permitted in exceptional cases involving severe fetal anomalies or conditions that endanger the mother’s life.

 

Option C. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case only if it threatens the life of the mother: This statement is incorrect. For 20-24 weeks POG, MTP is permitted not only for life-threatening conditions but also for cases involving rape, incest, disability, and minors.

 

Option D. MTP is permissible for 20-24 weeks POG in this case with 1 Doctor’s opinion only: This is incorrect because two doctors' opinions are required for high-risk cases between 20-24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP between 20-24 weeks of pregnancy is considered high risk and requires two doctors' opinions, especially in cases of rape, incest, disability, or if the woman is a minor.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with decreased hearing in higher frequencies. It was noted that the basilar membrane was affected. Which of the following structures lie near the affected structure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oval window

 

The affected structure in high-frequency hearing loss is the basal turn of the cochlea. Among the given options, the structure that lies near it is the oval window.

 

Movements of the stapes footplate, transmitted to the cochlear fluids, move the basilar membrane and set up shearing force between the tectorial membrane and the hair cells. The distortion of hair cells gives rise to cochlear microphonics, which trigger the nerve impulse. A sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment (travelling wave theory of von Bekesy). Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Modiolus: The central core of the cochlea around which the cochlear duct spirals. While important, it does not lie near the basal turn directly affected in high-frequency hearing loss.

 

Option B. Stria Vascularis: Located on the outer wall of the cochlear duct and is responsible for producing the endolymph. It plays a crucial role in maintaining the ionic composition of the endolymph but is not located near the oval window.

 

Option D. Helicotrema: The apex of the cochlea where the scala tympani and scala vestibuli meet, it is relevant for the transmission of lower frequency sounds, not high frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of high-frequency hearing loss, the basal turn of the cochlea near the oval window is typically involved. Understanding the anatomical proximity of the oval window to the basal turn helps in pinpointing the site of lesion and aids in specific diagnostic and therapeutic approaches aimed at the high-frequency hearing spectrum.

questions.text: Kienbock disease is caused by avascular necrosis of which of the following bones? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Lunate

 

Kienbock's disease refers to avascular necrosis of the lunate bone, which is one of the carpal bones in the wrist. It appears in the classification of common osteochondrites, which are a group of miscellaneous affections of growing epiphyses in children and adolescents. This condition typically presents with wrist pain, reduced grip strength, and limited wrist motion due to the compromised blood supply to the lunate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral neck - Avascular necrosis of the femoral neck is a different condition. In adults, it's simply called AVN of the femoral head, while in children it manifests as Perthes' disease (which affects the femoral head epiphysis, not the neck). The femoral head is particularly vulnerable to AVN due to its retrograde blood supply.

 

Option B. Medial cuneiform - There is no well-established avascular necrosis condition specifically named for the medial cuneiform bone. This bone is part of the midfoot and is not commonly affected by osteochondritis or avascular necrosis.

 

Option D. Scaphoid - While the scaphoid is prone to avascular necrosis, particularly after fracture due to its retrograde blood supply, this condition is not called Kienbock's disease. Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid typically occurs following scaphoid fractures and is not classified as an osteochondritis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Kienbock's disease specifically refers to avascular necrosis of the lunate bone, which is one of several named osteochondritis conditions affecting different bones throughout the body.

choices.text: Measles vaccine and Vitamin A supplementation

questions.text: An unvaccinated 4-year-old child presents with rashes, fever, and Bitot spot. This can be managed appropriately by: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isolation and Vitamin A supplementation

 

Explanation: 


When a child presents with measles (characterized by rashes, fever, and Bitot spots), the management involves two critical components:

 

  1. Isolation: Measles is highly contagious, so the child must be isolated to prevent spread to other individuals, especially those who are unvaccinated or immunocompromised.
  2. Vitamin A Supplementation: Vitamin A is crucial in managing measles because:
    • It reduces the severity of the disease
    • Decreases complications
    • Helps reduce mortality, especially in children with vitamin A deficiency
    • Supports immune system function during the infection

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Supportive care only: Incorrect. While supportive care is important, it is insufficient. Vitamin A supplementation is a critical intervention in measles management.

 

Option C. Measles vaccine and Vitamin A supplementation: Incorrect. Once a child has active measles, vaccination is no longer beneficial. The vaccine is preventive, not a treatment for ongoing infection.

 

Option D. Measles vaccine only: Incorrect. A child with active measles cannot be vaccinated during the acute phase of the illness. Vaccination is ineffective and potentially harmful at this stage.

 

Educational Objective: 


In active measles infection, isolation and Vitamin A supplementation are the key management strategies, with Vitamin A playing a crucial role in reducing disease severity and complications.

choices.text: Point B is 3 cm lateral to point A
Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal
Point A receives a dose of 7000 cGy
Point B receives a dose of 6000 cGy

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage 2B was advised radiotherapy. Which of the following statements regarding radiotherapy is false? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal

 

Point A

 

  • A point 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os.
  • Represents the anatomical location of the ureter.
  • The total dose to point A should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Point B

 

  • A point 3 cm lateral to point A.
  • Represents a dose to the pelvic wall.
  • The dose to point B is about 25 – 30% of the dose to point A (4500 – 6500 cGy).

 

False Statement Explanation

 

  • Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal:
    • This statement is false because Point A is defined as 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, not 5 cm lateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point A in cervical cancer radiotherapy is located 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, and the total dose should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Ref: Page no 350, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: The farmer presents with a cauliflower-like mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury, as depicted in the image. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of copper penny bodies. Based on this information, what is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chromoblastomycosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is chromoblastomycosis.

 

Chromoblastomycosis:

 

  • Causative Organism:  Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora species.
  • Clinical features: The initial presentation consists of warty papules that gradually enlarge, forming a hypertrophic plaque resembling cauliflower. Over the course of months to years, these lesions progress to large, hyperkeratotic masses with a surface often speckled with black dots.

 

 

Histopathology: Foreign body granuloma & Sclerotic / Medlar / Copper penny /Muriform bodies.

 

Treatment: Itraconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blastomycosis:

  • Caused by the fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis.
  • It primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other parts of the body, including the skin.
  • Skin manifestations can be ulcerative or verrucous but the presence of "copper penny bodies" is not a characteristic feature of this infection.
  • Thus, the microscopic finding does not match this option.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis/Rose Gardeners disease.

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear noduloulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Sporotrichoid lesions also seen in

 

  • FISH TANK/SWIMMING POOL GRANULOMA
  • LUPUS VULGARIS.

 

The given images show the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

Histopathology:  Asteroid bodies are seen.


Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Option D. Phaeohyphomycosis:

  • Represents a group of infections caused by various dematiaceous fungi.
  • Lesions can vary in appearance from nodules to cysts or abscesses.
  • Unlike chromoblastomycosis, phaeohyphomycosis does not characteristically have sclerotic or "copper penny" bodies under the microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its clinical presentation of verrucous skin lesions and the histopathological finding of sclerotic or copper penny bodies, indicative of infection with dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child came to the casualty with difficulty in walking and pain in the perianal region. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, yellow needle-shaped crystals are seen under the microscope. What is the test done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio’s Test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Option D. Acid phosphatase test: It’s a non-cellular Semen Markers i.e. markers are specific and unique to seminal plasma but independent of spermatozoa.

 

Finding a significantly elevated acid phosphatase level is consistent with the presence of semen. Undiluted semen has an acid phosphatase level of 340–360 Bodansky units/ml. A value of > 100 Bodansky units with/without motile sperms indicate that ejaculation occurred within 12 h of examination. Level decreases with time after intercourse, and there is little chance of identifying it after 48 h.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Non-cellular Semen Markers: Acid phosphatase test (quantitative), Prostate specific antigen or PSA (p30)

questions.text: Identify the structures as marked in the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Errector pili muscle

 

In the image, the marked structure corresponds to the Errector pili muscle (C).

Errector Pili Muscle is a tiny muscle attached to the base of a hair follicle. When this muscle contracts, it causes the hair to stand upright, a phenomenon known as "goosebumps."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sebaceous glands: Incorrect because the sebaceous glands are associated with hair follicles, but the marked structure is clearly a muscle, not a gland. Sebaceous Glands are small oil-producing glands present in the skin of mammals. They are usually associated with hair follicles and release sebum, which helps to lubricate the skin and hair.

 

Option B. Eccrine glands: Incorrect because these glands open directly onto the skin surface without any connection to the hair follicle, whereas the marked structure is connected to a hair follicle. Eccrine Glands are sweat glands that are not associated with hair follicles and play a key role in thermoregulation by secreting sweat.

 

Option D. Apocrine glands: Incorrect because apocrine glands are larger and typically located deeper in the dermis. These are sweat glands usually associated with hair follicles in areas such as the armpits and groin. They secrete a thicker, milky sweat that, when broken down by bacteria, can produce body odor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Errector pili muscle is a small muscle attached to hair follicles responsible for causing hairs to stand on end when contracted, leading to "goosebumps."

choices.text: Emergency cesarean facility should be there

questions.text: Correct about trial of labor in a previous LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section) is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency cesarean facility should be there

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is emergency cesarean facility should be there. When considering a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), it is crucial to ensure that the facility is equipped to handle an emergency cesarean section. This is because the risk of complications, including uterine rupture, can pose significant risks to both the mother and the fetus.

 

Emergency cesarean facility: The availability of an emergency cesarean section facility is essential for any patient undergoing TOLAC. This ensures that if complications arise, such as uterine rupture, immediate surgical intervention can be provided to minimize risks.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Risk of uterine rupture is 4-9%: This statement is incorrect for a lower segment cesarean section. The risk of uterine rupture in a TOLAC for a lower segment cesarean section is much lower, around 0.2%. The 4-9% risk applies to upper segment or classical cesarean sections.

 

Additional Considerations for TOLAC:

 

  1. Interval between pregnancies: The inter-delivery interval should be more than 18 months to allow adequate healing of the uterine scar.
  2. Reason for previous cesarean: Conditions like cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) or other recurrent indications may reduce the likelihood of a successful TOLAC and increase the risk of complications.
  3. Monitoring: Continuous fetal monitoring during labor is recommended to detect any signs of fetal distress early.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When attempting a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), ensure that an emergency cesarean facility is available to handle any complications, particularly the risk of uterine rupture.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male needs to be dressed in female lingerie and high heels to feel aroused and have intercourse with a female; he denies any sexual attraction towards males. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic fetishism

 

Transvestic fetishism involves the act of cross-dressing to achieve sexual arousal. In this case, the individual derives sexual excitement from wearing female clothing while engaging in sexual activity with females, which is characteristic of transvestic fetishism. He denies any attraction toward males, which further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender dysphoria involves a strong discomfort or distress with one’s assigned gender and a desire to be the opposite gender. There is no evidence in this scenario of dissatisfaction with his gender identity or discomfort with his sexual organs, ruling out gender dysphoria.

 

Option C. Homosexual orientation: Homosexual orientation refers to sexual attraction toward members of the same sex. The individual in this scenario specifically denies any sexual attraction to males, making this diagnosis inappropriate.

 

Option D. Testicular feminization: Testicular feminization, or Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome, is a genetic condition where an individual has a male karyotype (XY) but develops as a female due to insensitivity to androgens. This condition is unrelated to sexual arousal patterns or behaviors, and there is no evidence to support this diagnosis in the given context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic fetishism is characterized by sexual arousal from cross-dressing in individuals who do not have discomfort with their gender identity.

choices.text: Peak systolic velocity in the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA)

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation is undergoing routine obstetric evaluation. She has a history of Rh incompatibility, and recent laboratory results show the presence of elevated maternal anti-D antibody titers. The obstetrician is concerned about possible fetal anemia. Which of the following methods is most commonly used to assess fetal anemia in this situation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peak systolic velocity in the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA)

 

Explanation:

 

Fetal anemia in Rh-incompatible pregnancies is primarily assessed using Doppler ultrasound of the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA). The peak systolic velocity (PSV) of the MCA increases in response to anemia due to a brain-sparing effect, where blood flow is redistributed to essential organs like the brain.

 

  • When maternal anti-D titers are elevated, the fetus is monitored using MCA Doppler ultrasonography.
  • If the MCA-PSV is >1.5 multiples of the median (MoM) for gestational age, this suggests moderate-to-severe fetal anemia.
  • If significant anemia is suspected, cordocentesis (cord blood sampling) may be performed for direct measurement of fetal hemoglobin levels and possible intrauterine transfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cord blood sampling (Cordocentesis):

 

  • This is the gold standard for diagnosing fetal anemia but is an invasive procedure associated with risks like preterm labor and fetal loss. It is only performed when MCA Doppler findings suggest severe anemia.

 

Option B. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS):

 

  • This is used primarily for chromosomal and genetic analysis in the first trimester.
  • It has no role in detecting fetal anemia.

 

Option D. Umbilical artery Doppler:

 

  • This is used in cases of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) to assess placental insufficiency.
  • It is not useful for detecting fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA-PSV) is the most commonly used non-invasive method to assess fetal anemia in cases of Rh incompatibility. A value greater than 1.5 MoM indicates moderate-to-severe anemia, warranting further invasive testing like cordocentesis.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ig A

 

The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

 

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

 

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

 

  • ﻿﻿J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • ﻿﻿Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ig G: Typically exists as a monomer and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the blood and extracellular fluid.

 

Option C. Ig M: The largest antibody, mainly in pentameric form, being the first antibody to be produced in response to an infection.

 

Option D. Ig E: Involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections, known for its role in the immune response to allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

choices.text: Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing
Telomerase is found in somatic cells

questions.text: True about telomeres and telomerase is:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gradually decreasing length of telomeres with ageing

 

This statement is correct. Telomeres naturally shorten with each cell division, and this gradual shortening is associated with the aging process. It's a result of the end replication problem, where the DNA replication machinery cannot fully replicate the ends of linear chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased telomere length with ageing: This statement is incorrect. Telomeres, the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, tend to shorten with each cell division and are associated with aging. Over time, this can contribute to cellular senescence and aging.

 

Option C. Telomeres have coding sequences: This statement is incorrect. Telomeres do not contain coding sequences for proteins. Instead, they consist of repetitive DNA sequences that provide a buffer zone to protect the essential genetic information during cell division.

 

Option D. Telomerase is found in somatic cells: This statement is generally incorrect. Telomerase, the enzyme that can counteract telomere shortening by adding repetitive DNA sequences, is typically more active in germ cells and certain stem cells. In most somatic cells, telomerase activity is low, contributing to the progressive shortening of telomeres with each cell division.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telomeres are end of chromosomes and do not contain any coding sequences. Instead it has TTAGGG sequence repeated ‘n’ no. of times.

 

Telomerase is enzyme present only in the germ/stem cells and is responsible for maintaining the length of telomeres due to its RNA dependent DNA polymerase activity.

 

In Somatic cells, absence of telomerase enzyme (option d is false) results in telomere shortening as the cells ages.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 355, 716

questions.text: Where is use of this instrument contra-indicated? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obstructed labor

 

  • This image shows an obstetric forceps. 
  • Forceps are contraindicated in obstructed labor because attempting instrumental delivery in this condition would be dangerous and fatal. In obstructed labor, the fetus cannot descend through the birth canal due to mechanical obstruction, making it a direct indication for cesarean section. Any attempt at instrumental delivery could cause serious maternal and fetal trauma.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cesarean section: Incorrect. Forceps can be used during cesarean section, especially with a mobile free-floating head. For deeply engaged heads, one blade of the forceps can be used to dislodge the head.

 

Option B. After coming head of breech: Incorrect. Piper's forceps are specifically designed and commonly used for delivering the after-coming head in breech deliveries.

 

Option D. Occipito posterior: Incorrect. Forceps can be safely used in occipito posterior position. The baby will be delivered face-to-pubis, but both forceps and vacuum extraction are acceptable options.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Obstructed labor is an absolute contraindication for instrumental delivery (both forceps and vacuum) and is a direct indication for cesarean section.

choices.text: Head 1/5th palpable per abdomen
Head on perineum

questions.text: Outlet forceps is applied at what station? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Head on perineum

 

Outlet forceps are used when the fetal head is at the outlet of the birth canal, which means the head is visible at the perineum. This typically corresponds to a station of +4 or +5 depending on the system used, but "head on perineum" is the most accurate description.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head 1/5th palpable per abdomen: This indicates that the head is still relatively high in the birth canal and not at the outlet.

 

Option B. 0 station: This is when the fetal head is at the level of the ischial spines, which is too high for outlet forceps application.

 

Option C. +2 station: This indicates the fetal head is descending but not yet at the perineum. Low forceps might be used at this station, but not outlet forceps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Outlet forceps are applied when the fetal head is visible at the perineum, indicating it is at the outlet of the birth canal.
